channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: Russian Strikes on Odesa Raise Doubts About Grain Deal
item.description: A Ukrainian official said that Russian strikes had caused 10 explosions in Odesa on Saturday, one day after the warring sides agreed to a deal to help transport millions of tons of grain out of that port and others on the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: Below an Israeli City, a Musical Harmony Belies the Tensions Above Ground
item.description: In an underground reservoir built 1,233 years ago in a city that saw sectarian riots last year, visitors hear a beguiling musical composition that combines Arab love songs with Hebrew poetry.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Visitors at the Pool of the Arches, a subterranean reservoir beneath Ramla, a city in Israel with a mixed population of Arabs and Jews.

item.title: In Japan, Abe Suspect’s Grudge Against Unification Church Is a Familiar One
item.description: The man accused of killing Shinzo Abe said his mother’s huge donations to the church bankrupted his family. Many others in Japan have similar stories.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Kyodo/Reuters
item.media:description: Tomihiro Tanaka, president of the Japanese branch of the Unification Church, during a moment of silence for former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at a Tokyo news conference last week.

item.title: Amid Sri Lanka’s Crisis, Cricket Carries On
item.description: The success of the men’s national team has offered solace to the country, and one fan called the players “brand ambassadors during this time of hardship.”
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Eranga Jayawardena/Associated Press
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters atop a 17th- century fort overlooking the cricket stadium in Galle, Sri Lanka, while the home team played Australia in June.

item.title: Draghi’s Fall Reverberates Beyond Italy
item.description: The downfall of Italy’s prime minister has raised concerns across Europe about the power of populist movements and whether they will erode unity against Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Andreas Solaro/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi at the Senate on Wednesday in Rome.

item.title: Sri Lankan Forces Raid Protest Camp
item.description: The predawn raid in Colombo on Friday caught demonstrators by surprise. The police detained at least nine people.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Rafiq Maqbool/Associated Press
item.media:description: Soldiers outside the Presidential Secretariat in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Friday after the raid on the protest site there.

item.title: ​South Korea’s New President Calls for Criminal Investigation of Past Government
item.description: Newly released photos of two North Korean men being deported under Moon Jae-in have revived accusations of a potential “crime against humanity.”
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Yonhap/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Moon Jae-in, left, then South Korea’s president, with Yoon Suk-yeol in March, soon after Mr. Yoon’s victory in the presidential election.

item.title: Mossad Sheds New Light on Argentina Terrorist Attacks in 1990s
item.description: An investigation by the Israeli spy agency found that Hezbollah had set up a cell to conduct the attacks and rejected suspicions that Argentines or Iranian officials in Buenos Aires had been involved.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Enrique G. Medina/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A billboard in Buenos Aires with the names of victims of a July 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in the city. The sign at the top reads, “Remembering the endless pain.”

item.title: After Mocking France’s Literary Elite, a Fraught Invite Into the Club
item.description: Mohamed Mbougar Sarr, a Senegal-born writer, has won high praise and top prizes from Paris’s insular publishing establishment. But the novelist wonders: Is it an endorsement or “a way to silence me”?
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Last year Mohamed Mbougar Sarr won France’s top literary prize, the Goncourt, established in 1903.

item.title: Attack on Base in Mali Brings Conflict to Doorstep of Capital
item.description: Insurgents used two booby-trapped vehicles full of explosives in the raid, the West African nation’s military said. The uptick in violence has come as French troops prepare to leave the country.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.media:description: An armored personnel carrier at the main military base outside Bamako, the capital of Mali, after an attack on Friday.

item.title: The Race to Succeed Boris Johnson, Explained
item.description: A former top finance official, Rishi Sunak, and the foreign secretary, Liz Truss, are competing to replace Britain’s departing prime minister. Here’s a guide to the contest.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Neil Hall/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Outside 10 Downing Street, the prime minister’s official residence in London.

item.title: Deep in a Covid Wave, Europe Counts Cases and Carries On
item.description: Even in countries that once took strict measures, the authorities are relying on vaccination and past infections to take the sting out of Omicron subvariants.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Fabio Frustaci/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Crowds around the Trevi Fountain in Rome earlier this month. Reported coronavirus cases in Italy have risen steadily since mid-June.

item.title: India’s Next President Will Make History When She’s Sworn In
item.description: Droupadi Murmu, who was elected to the largely ceremonial post this week, will be the first president from one of India’s Indigenous tribes.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Divyakant Solanki/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Droupadi Murmu, a former governor of Jharkhand State and a member of the Santhal tribe, will be sworn in as India’s 15th president next week.

item.title: W.H.O. Declares Monkeypox Spread a Global Health Emergency
item.description: There have been more than 16,000 cases outside Africa, and the virus has reached 75 countries and territories.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Monkeypox vaccines were still in short supply when the World Health Organization declared the virus’s spread a global health emergency.

item.title: Four Things Nations Can Do to Conserve Energy
item.description: European Union officials have called on countries in the bloc to sharply reduce their natural gas consumption. These are some of the strategies they could use.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Dominic Lipinski/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Greenwich Park, in southeast London, on Monday. Temperatures in the city surpassed 104 degrees Fahrenheit this week.

item.title: Indoor Games
item.description: When it’s more comfortable inside than out, it’s time to play games.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Times’s Theater Critic Reviews Stratford’s New Theater
item.description: The Stratford Festival in Ontario opened a glamorous new theater last month that prioritizes the theater itself, not just what surrounds it.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green

item.title: How the Government Is Failing Americans Uprooted by Natural Disaster
item.description: Climate change is creating a growing class of displaced Americans, and the federal government is struggling to decide how to help them.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Edmund Fountain

item.title: Most U.S. States Have Let Their Covid Emergencies Expire
item.description: The wider latitude conferred by a state’s public health emergency was critical to states’ responses to earlier waves of coronavirus cases.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Public school students and staff members from Clayton County, Ga., waited for coronavirus tests in January.

item.title: Russia Agrees to Let Ukraine Ship Grain, Easing World Food Shortage
item.description: Ukraine and Russia signed a deal to lift Russia’s blockade of Ukrainian ports, which has worsened a global food crisis — their most important agreement since the war began.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A barley field in the Mykolaiv region of Ukraine, in June.

item.title: ‘The deal should help us breathe’: Africa welcomes Russia-Ukraine grain deal.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Eduardo Soteras/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Workers unloaded sacks of grain at a market in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, last month.

item.title: See How Far Water Levels in Lake Mead Have Fallen
item.description: New satellite images of the reservoir, a critical source of water for 25 million people, reveal dangerously low water levels.
item.dc:creator: Winston Choi-Schagrin

item.title: Germany bails out a crucial gas provider squeezed by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Matthias Schrader/Associated Press
item.media:description: A gas storage facility run by Uniper near Munich.

item.title: What to Know About the Marburg Virus Disease
item.description: Two people infected with the virus died in Ghana last month, though no other cases were found, experts said. The disease’s fatality rate is high.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.media:credit: Photo by Bonnie Jo Mount/The Washington Post via Getty Images
item.media:description: Researchers gathering bats in 2018 at Queen Elizabeth National Park in Uganda to study the animals’ role in transmission of the Marburg virus.

item.title: How the Grain Deal Between Ukraine and Russia Will Work
item.description: The process requires the collaboration of the two warring nation, along with Turkey and the United Nations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grain bins storing corn, wheat, sunflower and soybeans in Boryspil, Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Gas prices Have Fallen Offering Reprieve in US
item.description: Prices have now fallen for more than a month.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gas prices have been falling for over a month.

item.title: 1947: Deadly Volcanic Eruption in Nicaragua Menaces Nearby City
item.description: Hot rocks and ash were spewed over the countryside, destroying some of the Central American country’s richest farmland and leaving thousands homeless.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: As Covid Cases Rise Again, No Clear Guidance From the Top
item.description: Omicron subvariants are driving a winter surge in Australia, but officials’ health advice has been confusing, to put it mildly.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Asanka Ratnayake/Getty Images
item.media:description: Masking up in Melbourne on Thursday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A possible deal on Ukraine’s blocked grain.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O’Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russia’s blockage of Ukraine’s grain exports has been among the gravest international repercussions of Moscow’s invasion.

item.title: Russia Moves to Close Agency Handling Emigration to Israel
item.description: For years, Vladimir Putin worked to rebuild ties to Russia’s Jews, but the new move against a Jewish nonprofit has raised questions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Evgenia Novozhenina/Reuters
item.media:description: The entrance in Moscow to a Russian branch of the Jewish Agency for Israel, which the Russian government is seeking to shut down.

item.title: Putin Is ‘Entirely Too Healthy,’ C.I.A. Director Says
item.description: There is no evidence that the Russian president is unwell, Western intelligence officials said, after the Kremlin denied rumors about his health.
item.dc:creator: Maham Javaid
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during this week’s summit with the leaders of Iran and Turkey in Tehran.

item.title: Trees Dedicated to Holocaust Victims Are Destroyed at Buchenwald
item.description: Seven trees near the former concentration camp in Germany were chopped down in what the International Committee of Buchenwald Dora said was a “horrible act of vandalism.”
item.dc:creator: Claire Fahy
item.media:credit: Bodo Schackow/picture alliance via Getty Images
item.media:description: The trees were among the 168 planted along the route that Buchenwald prisoners were forced to march in April 1945.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Ukraine Launches a Southern Counteroffensive
item.description: Also, President Biden tests positive for Covid and Europe’s central bank raises its rates.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians firing towards Russian controlled territory in the Donetsk region on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden Has Begun Taking Paxlovid, an Antiviral Medication
item.description: Researchers are still working to answer key questions about the drug, including how effective it is in vaccinated people and whether cases of “rebounding” in people who receive it are common.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.media:description: Pfizer's Paxlovid antiviral medication.

item.title: Vice President Kamala Harris Tests Negative
item.description: Ms. Harris last saw President Biden two days before he tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris with President Biden at the White House, in May.

item.title: Turkey says a deal between Ukraine and Russia to unblock grain exports will be signed on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Farnaz Fassihi, Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Safak Timur and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A storage facility for grain on the outskirts of Lviv, Ukraine, in May.

item.title: Ukraine Tries to Make the Case That It Can Win the War
item.description: Pushing back against skepticism that Western weapons will allow them to turn the tide against Russia, Ukrainians point to successful attacks using new long-range rocket systems.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians firing towards Russian controlled territory in the Donetsk region on Tuesday.

item.title: Colorado River Reservoirs Run Critically Low. States Must Submit Cuts.
item.description: The federal government has told states to agree on urgent water cuts to ensure dams can keep generating power. Researchers say reductions once considered “unthinkable” may be necessary in the long term.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo from March shows Lone Rock Beach on Lake Powell in Utah, an area that used to be underwater.

item.title: Risk From Covid-19 Is Increasing in Much of the U.S.
item.description: Still, many Americans have turned their attention away from the pandemic, and many health officials have grown more hesitant to sound the alarm.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Christopher (KS) Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: A nurse with the Jackson County Health Department administered a coronavirus test at a drive-through testing site in Independence, Mo., on July 13.

item.title: BBC Apologizes to Royal Nanny Swept Up in Diana Reporting Furor
item.description: Suggestions that a nanny for the children of Princess Diana and Prince Charles was involved with the prince were “wholly baseless,” the British broadcaster said as it agreed to pay her damages.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Aaron Chown/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Alexandra Pettifer, the former Tiggy Legge-Bourke, outside High Court in London on Thursday.

item.title: In Washington, Olena Zelenska Dressed for Ukraine
item.description: On an unofficial visit, the Ukrainian first lady represents her country in more ways than one.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Patrick Semansky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Ms. Zelenska in the olive green dress and flower pin she wore on her visit to Washington.

item.title: Australia Avoids Reimposing Covid Rules as Hospitalizations Surge
item.description: Early in the pandemic, the country had some of the world’s strictest rules, but a new government is reluctant to bring them back.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Diego Fedele/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Australia is approaching its highest number of hospitalizations of the pandemic.

item.title: Russia Restarts Gas Shipments Through Pipeline, but Keeps Germany Guessing
item.description: Russia is again sending natural gas through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline to Germany, but nobody knows how much and how long the fuel will flow.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Jens Buettner/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pipe systems of the Nord Stream 1 Baltic Sea pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: Belgium Ratifies Prisoner-Exchange Treaty With Iran
item.description: Critics say that Belgium is giving into Iranian blackmail in order to secure the release of one of its nationals in Iran and that the treaty will put more Belgians in the country in danger.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Dirk Waem/AFP via Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters outside the Antwerp criminal court during the trial last year of Assadollah Assadi, an Iranian diplomat.

item.title: Monarch Butterflies Are Placed on IUCN Red List
item.description: Researchers cited climate change and habitat loss. But they also said the public can help give the insects a boost.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Red List decision covers migratory monarch butterflies in North America.

item.title: Russia continues to bombard Kharkiv despite little recent progress in Moscow’s eastern campaign.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A damaged apartment complex in Kharkiv last week.

item.title: The Latest Covid Surge and What it Means for the U.S.
item.description: We look at what it means for the country.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masked pedestrians in New York in May.

item.title: Ukrainian troops gain confidence after retaking a village.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall and Mauricio Lima

item.title: Italy’s President Accepts Draghi Resignation, Calling for New Elections
item.description: Italy now ends a period of relative stability and influence and faces the prospect of a chaotic campaign that a right-wing alliance is best positioned to win.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Fabio Frustaci/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mario Draghi, center, acknowledging applause in the Italian Parliament on Thursday.

item.title: An An, World’s Oldest Giant Male Panda in Captivity, Dies at 35
item.description: The animal was euthanized in Hong Kong on Thursday because of his deteriorating health, a statement said.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Jerome Favre/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: An An at Ocean Park in Hong Kong in 2020. In recent weeks, he was refusing solid foods. His diet swayed far from the daily intake of 30 pounds of bamboo that giant pandas normally eat.

item.title: Russia resumes gas flow through key pipeline to Germany.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Nord Stream 1 Baltic Sea pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: Russia Restarts Gas Flow Through Key Pipeline to Germany
item.description: The suspense was another reminder of the reliance of Germany, and much of the rest of Europe, on Russian energy. European Union leaders urged members to cut natural gas use immediately.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy and Marc Santora

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: The E.U. plans to ration gas.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Stefan Sauer/DPA, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Russia may limit the amount of gas it sends to Germany through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline.

item.title: The C.I.A. Director Says Putin Believes the U.S. Will Forget About Ukraine
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: William J. Burns, the C.I.A. director, in Washington in March.

item.title: Russia orders search engines to put a disclaimer on Wikipedia results it claims are ‘fakes.’
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Dmitry Azarov/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signed into law a measure intended to silence war critics earlier this year.

item.title: Russia Signals That It May Want a Bigger Chunk of Ukraine
item.description: A top Russian official said Moscow may extend its territorial claims to include not just the east of Ukraine but also parts of the south.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers watching emergency workers in the rubble of a house hit by rockets Tuesday on the outskirts of Sloviansk, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Covid-related international travel restrictions continue to wane.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Gabriella N. Baez/Reuters
item.media:description: The British Virgin Islands dropped all of its coronavirus testing requirements last week.
